notes:
1. Invariant Reactions

Invariant reactions are transformations that occur at a specific temperature and composition where three phases are in equilibrium. The key invariant points on the Fe-Fe₃C diagram are the eutectoid, eutectic, and peritectic points.

2. Eutectoid Point

This is the most important point for steel heat treatment.

  • Location: Occurs at 0.77% Carbon and 727°C (1341°F).
  • Reaction: Upon slow cooling, one solid phase (Austenite) transforms into two other solid phases (Ferrite and Cementite).
    • $$ Austenite (\gamma) \xrightarrow{Cooling} Ferrite (\alpha) + Cementite (Fe_3C) $$

    The resulting layered microstructure is called Pearlite.

3. Eutectic Point

This point is important for cast irons.

  • Location: Occurs at 4.3% Carbon and 1148°C (2098°F).
  • Reaction: Upon slow cooling, a liquid phase transforms directly into two solid phases (Austenite and Cementite).
    • $$ Liquid (L) \xrightarrow{Cooling} Austenite (\gamma) + Cementite (Fe_3C) $$

4. Peritectic Point

This reaction is of less practical importance for most common steels.

  • Location: Occurs at 0.18% Carbon and 1495°C (2723°F).
  • Reaction: Upon slow cooling, a liquid phase and a solid phase react to form a new solid phase.
    • $$ Liquid (L) + Delta\ Ferrite (\delta) \xrightarrow{Cooling} Austenite (\gamma) $$

solvedExamples.question: The eutectoid reaction in the iron-carbon system involves the transformation of:

options.text: One solid into a liquid and another solid.
One solid into two different solids.
A liquid into a single solid.

solvedExamples.explanation: The eutectoid reaction is a solid-state reaction where a single solid phase (Austenite) transforms into two new solid phases (Ferrite and Cementite) upon cooling.

solvedExamples.question: At what carbon concentration does the eutectoid reaction occur in steel?
solvedExamples.explanation: The eutectoid composition for an iron-carbon alloy is approximately 0.77% carbon by weight. A steel with this composition is called a eutectoid steel and will transform entirely into pearlite upon slow cooling.
